Beer. (Which would be my entire review, were it not for RBs 75-character requirement.) That is to say, Anchor California Lager is beer at its most basic, recognizable form, a step up from macro swill yet tracing a direct line from cheap industrial crap to craft quality. Hits all the lager requirements: moderately sweet malts, fruity apple notes coming from the yeast, mild Euro-hop finish tightening up the back end. A beer-tasting beer, without any noticeable flaws yet also lacking any discernible traits to make it stand out. Not bad, not by a long shot. Just normal.

355ml can from Tesco. Served cold from the fridge as befits a beer drunk for refreshment. There is a pleasant fruitiness to this which suggests a more active yeast than is commonly used in lagers, or perhaps the temperature was slightly hotter during fermentation, or they didnt ferment out fully. Whatever, its nice to get some malt character in a lager. The old fashioned hop, Cluster, is my kind of hop. Balanced and restrained and subtle. It is earthy and floral and fruity - bringing in a dusty and thirst-quenching bitterness, but also imparting a bright thin fruit, which complements and enhances the fruitiness of the malt. This beer doesnt taste American at all - this is like something from Syria or Africa. It has a wild and wonderful crudeness and character and genuine flavour. It tastes of beer, not of hops, and the malt is rough and complex and quite delightful. I havent enjoyed a lager this much for ages. Not that Im getting carried away, but I certainly would be interested in trying this again at a warmer temperature to see what it really tastes like.

In which I live up to the first half of my RB name.  So tonight I figured Id hit Mikkeller for dinner and a beer or two. I head over there at 6:00 and the place is fucking packed, and Im like, "nope, not waiting in a line to spend too much on beer." So I went back to my hotel, watched some football, talked to my family, and ironed my poster for tomorrow. By 8:30 Im thinking I should give food another go, and since I dont have a better plan I go back to Mikkeller again. I dont even know why -- theres nothing on draft Im dying to try and I dont even like the place to tell you the truth. But whatever, Im in a rut, so I head back. And its less busy now ... but still way too busy. So Im all "fuck this, Im gonna go get food somewhere else," and I head into the Tenderloin in search of food. I never found any, but I found something better -- Emperor Nortons Boozeland. This place is chill, and even though there are no empty spots at the first bar around the other side is mostly empty. I stake out a spot and order this beer. And its fucking great. Cold, crisp, refreshing, crushable. I could drink this all night. Seriously, the feeling drinking this is that its the best beer Ive had all trip, and that says something considering I was at Russian River and City Beer yesterday. Now all thats missing is somebody to talk to. Im sitting all alone in my own little corner of the bar (while still being *at* the bar ... just half behind a wall). And so Im sitting there, crushing this fucking great beer that I could drink all night, staring off into a corner thinking about what an introverted weirdo Ive turned out to be, when out of nowhere a guy in an ill-fitting suit walks over to me, and says, "hey ... you here all alone? I dont want to impose, I mean, who knows, maybe this what you want to do. But Im here with a bunch of people, we just had a work christmas party, and were all on the other side of that wall -- you know, if you want to hang out and talk to people." I shit you not, this is what he said to me, just as Im reflecting on how lonely the night is turning out to be and my inexplicable inability to just reach out and connect with another human being. Im not sure if hes hitting on me or not, but we chat for a few minutes and it all seems cool before he reiterates the invite and heads back to his party, and Im thinking this sounds like it could be exactly what tonight needs. The bartender sees my empty glass and asks if I want another, to which I reply, "I ... dont know. Maybe? ... No, think Ill call it a night."

A soft pour from the can into my globe glass produces a three-finger thick, light tan colored head; the head is quite dense, and has lots of staying power, including leaving some lacing patterns on the sides of my glass. The beer is a nice golden copper hue that shows a clear, bright golden hue when held up to the light. The aroma is hop dominant, though the overall effect is low; notes of black currants, a slight metallic hop character, grassy herbal notes, and a touch of menthol are all noticeable. The hop aromatics are backed by cracker leaning, with just a touch of English biscuit maltiness.

Nicely balanced between malt and hop in the flavor, the beer has a nice clean flavor to it, except towards the finish where the hop character has an herbal, sort of metallic edge to it that is nice. The bitterness is nicely bitting from beginning to end, and this balances the light, chewy, cracker / bread like malt sweetness that is here. Touches of menthol, a bit of black currant, with a grassy herbal character, and even a touch of bright citrus zest round out the hop notes here. The body has a touch of viscosity to it that provides some palate heft, yet is still eminently quaffable, just as it should be.

From M&S. Well, the faux-sunfaded bear emblazoned bottle, historical blurb and resplendent anchor crown all score bonus points as, lets be honest, these things matter. But my overriding impression? Thank God were not trapped in 1876 with no more than Cluster to brew with. Bizarre English chipshop batter, dried tea leaf, dewy grass, fennel, marzipan nose. Clear medium golden in color with a moderately foamy, lasting white head, and plenty of visible effervescence. Flavor profile is pretty well balanced with a good bit of spicy hoppiness throughout, more crackery/biscuity malt here as well as a fairly strong dosage of hop bitterness towards the finish, this straying a bit towards metallic. Palate is quite dry and high in carbonation, body is light-medium. Surprisingly flavorful. Very nice as a warm-weather quencher and all-around general purpose lager.  Unsurprisingly, tastes like what you might imagine a beer from the 19th century would.

Tasted as Anchor California Lager. I guess Anchor wouldnt be Anchor if no Californian tradition, in this case the Cluster hops, would be attached to it somehow. Pours a deep old gold colour, yellow blonde with an ever so subtle olive hue, very slightly hazy and with calm but steady sparkling; the very lightly greyish white head, medium thick and moussy, stays closed and densely packed the whole time and makes a clearly audible crackling sound for minutes on end. Weak and pretty straightforward, but pleasant and sweet aroma of freshly baked cake, perhaps a suggestion of dried apricot, white bread, baked banana, honey, leafy and earthy hops. Neutral onset, very lightly metallic, with sharpish carbonation, quickly becoming sourish and minerally, tingling on the palate and tongue and even numbing them for a moment, proceeding in a light but delicately bready malt sweetishness and ending in a fairly hoppy, quenching finish, leafy and grassy, pretty floral too (almost honeyish), bittering and of medium length. Worthy premium lager, and if this class is to be considered as the next best thing to a classical Pilsener, Im willing to stand up for classifying this as a genuine Pilsener - and a good one at that. The Anchor brewery, as the grandfather of American craft beer culture, has always more or less restrained from wild experiments and keeps thing simple, but never disappoints. Very decent, to say the least.

Malt, wheat, caramel, candy, yeast, spices. Good balance with respectable ABV. Medium body, average-quick duration. I need to drink premium lagers more. Good stuff.
Light gold with a medium head. Musty grain and slightly buttery aroma. Barley flavor. Noble, grassy hops. Almost some fruit in the finish. Light bitterness.

Yellow-golden pour with small white head. Aroma is bread, cookies, grass, spice, lemon. Taste is light grain and water, a vague hint of bitterness. Very smooth mouthfeel. Great aroma but too watery, even for a lager.

UPDATED: JUL 12, 2015 Bottle into pint glass, light orangy-golden color with white head. Aroma of baked bread and floral/grassy hop notes. Taste adds notes of straw, citrus, toast and faint caramel. Light body, moderate-low carbonation, crisp with mild grassy bitter finish. Pretty good simple lager.

(Anchor California Lager) Bottle 355ml at home, poured into a lager glass, ABV 4.9%
Golden orange colour on the body, tall white and thick head on top, with very good retention, leaving heavy lacing on the glass.
Light caramel on the aroma but other than that standard lager aroma, only a bit fresher, malts fresh grass.
Malty taste,some bread and cookie dough, grass. Nice intense bitterness on the aftertaste.
Medium thin body, nicely carbonated. Quite dry on the palate.
Quite good.

12oz bottle into a pint glass.

Pours a slightly hazy light gold with a fairly thick for the style one finger white head. Good head retention although lacing is a bit lacking.

Aroma is very bready with some light floral and grassy notes from the hops. Anchor uses cluster hops in this and it does have that distinct American lager aroma.

Bready grain in the flavor along with a very prominent hop note of grass/hay like what was present in the aroma. Bitterness is moderate but does remain restrained. Extremely clean finish with incredible drink ability.

This might be one of the best pre-prohibition lagers I have had. It is a very clean beer with just enough bitterness to balance things out. Its crazy to think this is what American lagers used to taste like
12 oz bottle. Pours a clear gold with a white head. Has an odd very tart apple/pear aroma. Light caramel and biscuit flavors, honey, with some of those pear notes around the edges. Eh.

Pours a clear amber gold with two fingers of white head. Aroma is corn and slight malt. Flavor is slightly sweet and some corn. Slight floral aroma also. Nice beer.

12oz bottle. Medium white head atop crystal clear apple juice body. Aroma is medium sweet, straw, some spicy, wort, bread. Taste is medium sweet, orange, straw, some toast/bread, spicy, grapefruit/lemon, light caramel. Light body, light effervescence, somewhat watery, nicely drinkable.

0,355 l bottle 
bread, hay, cereal, herbs, basement aromas, golden, clear, frothy, white foam, medium sweetness, lightly bitter, medium body, oily feel, slick feel, soft carbonation,

Bottle. Pale yellow pour, nice thick head for a lager. Aroma is classic lager, but without being grainy or skunky. Flavour is light malty with a subtle but recognizable hop kick. No cheap grainy notes. Very little carbonation and an ultra-smooth, almost buttery full-bodied texture. An impressive lager if there ever was one.
bottle into glass, orangish clear pour with white head, fuky skunk aroma, taste is bitter malts, meh, not again
Shared with McTapps. Classic Lager with a nice touch of grass, some straw and hay. Easily drinkable and a soul of a Zwickel. To recommend.

Bottle from Rudat in Dortmund. Pours out in a clear golden colour with steady low ehad and medium body. Aroma of hops and straw. Taste of hops, light malt, mild citrus fruits, straw and grains. Bready finish. Not a bad one.

Bottle poured into chilled pint glass. Very nice lacing, medium/low head with good retention and nice effervescence, little bubbles the entire duration of the beer. Good medium gold color, mild aroma and taste as expected of a pale lager, but with a quality palate of flavors from start to finish reflecting the quality ingredients. Very good and refreshing beer, probably my second pale lager regularly available after the new Belgium shift.

A golden beer with a medium and blond head. The nose has malts, some grass and hint of fruits. Taste has malts, some fruits, grass and some bitterness. Medium bodied, medium carbonation. Basic lager but brewed nicely.

12 oz. can. Golden with a lasting film of cream. Nose is toffee, fresh apple, toasted corn, citrus zest and spicy dry grass. Taste is caramel with some stale tart apple, cardboard, citrus zest, corn and dry grass. Near-medium body is to the sweet side but finishes crisp. Nice low-medium carbonation.
Dunkel goldenes Bier mit schöner Schaumkrone. Geruch malzig, leicht hopfig. Geschmack sehr malzig, etwas fruchtig, würzig.

Pours a crisp and clear golden color. Nice white foamy 2 finger head that drops to a one finger pillow. A nice malty and cereal aroma with hints of resin and a nice touch of floral notes. Very refreshing aroma. Good lager taste which keeps that maltiness from the scent. Refreshing mouth feel with plenty of carbonation and light hop/bitter flavor on the back end. Overall a very nice lager to kick back with in the heat.
Light golden colored pour. Big white head. Plenty of lacing. Crisp hop and malt aroma. Bitter.
From notes......bottle at home. Aroma of dried fruits. Fresh. Flavor is crisp hops, fruity, grain. Tastes like a Sam Adams. Crisp, dry, refreshing finish.

Cool looking can compliments of another6pack. Thanks, Trent for this and the OTHER 17 beers you sent me.

12oz can.

I didnt chill the can long enough as the pour brought a 3 finger head of foam but no worries, Im a patient guy.

I now see a light golden coloured brew that now has a 1 finger HOF sitting on top. The foam shrinkage left some lacing.

It smells really toasty, a bit grainy, with a light nondescript bitterness. 

The taste is very nice. A good toasted malt flavour backed up by grain and a pleasant citrus hop kick that keeps that toast from being TOO toasty. Yes siree, this is an easy drinker. 

Light bodied, goodly amount of carbonation.

Wow, that can went quickly. Proof positive, that I dig it.

12oz bottle poured into a shaker glass.
Clear golden color with a small and quickly diminishing white head.
Grassy nose, with floral notes, some malt and faint fruitiness. 
Clean light malt flavors, pleasant bitterness, grass and faint apple notes.
Light bodied, balanced, some minor harsh aftertaste but overall very decent.
On tap at RJ. Pours golden color, white head. Aroma is malty, floral hoppy, bit citrusy. Taste is medium sweet, malty, yeasty, floral hops.
Vycap Richtar Jakub. Zlata cira farba, biela pena. Vona sladova, kvetinova. V chuti sladka sladovost, kvetinky, lahka horkost.
Smooth and sessionable, but nothing special. Goldish color. Grain, corn, a little bit of hop. Light and crisp.
low in alcohol but high on taste. Better than your average lager but not by much. Has a dryness that puts it ahead of other similar beers.
Bottle 0,335ltr: Almost clear and golden colored with an perfect bitter taste for an lager. I have a soft spot for quite sometime for this San Fransiscan brewery.

Pours slightly hazy straw color with fizzy white head. Strong yeast esters dominate the aroma with some underlying fruity apple juice notes. Flavor is very yeasty with light hopped imparting a little bitterness and a little sweetness but neither are singly dominant.

355 ml bottle. Pours a golden colour with a small head. Aroma of grains, honey sweetness and grass. Flavour of grainy malts, mild bitterness, pear sweetness and herbs. Light bodied. Soft carbonation. Decent.
Draught at Fate Brewing. Amber color, white head. Bitter taste with hops, citrus, toast, malts and a bit of pine. Bitter finish with hops, citrus and toast. Very nice lager.

35,5 cl bottle as Anchor California Lager@ hotel room, Amsterdam. BBE 01/2016
Aroma is sweetish, musty and somewhat heavy with apricot and malt. Flavour has apricot, peaches, toffee typical to English ales and hints of grassy hops in the finish. Unusual lager, tastes like English pale ale.

Pours a clear orange with a good head from a can. Light medium lager sour aroma pretty decent. More flavor than a typical lager and bitter like my wife. A little bitter but not much but definitely making a point.

Lightly misty golden body with excellent head. Classic aroma, well present quality pilsner malts, never metallic or sweet. Excellently developed and although its a bit underhopped it makes this very drinkable. Dry bodied, quite clean. Very nice to drink and easy to drink fast, despite the active carbonation. A classically build yet modernly executed and thirst quenching lager. Nice one. (Bottle from Saveur Bière)
Flesje uit de VS. Helder oranjegoudkleurig met witte kraag. Behoorlijk bitter en droog. Weinig fruit, klein beetje perzik. Behoorlijk pittig biertje voor zijn stijl.
Dark gold, decent sized white head. Smells clean, crisp. Taste is...I dunno, beer? Nothing too fancy, just a clean crisp lager, with a touch of sweetness. I liked it...
Bottle from Convi.  Deep golden color with thick white head. Malty aroma with hoppy touch.Malty taste with grassy hops. Hoppy bitterness in finish. Good.

355ml bottle. BBE 01/16. As California lager. Clear golden, thick white head. Typical oremium lager aroma, grainy malt, some hops. Flavor has grain, hay, hops. Nice dry bitter finish. Clean brew.-- rated with beerbasher/winphone
This was a pleasant surprise. I havent found a great appreciation for Anchor beers. This was a solid beer with a nice malty backbone and hop balance finishes slightly bitter.

[Rating from a bottle of Anchor California Lager] Californians make so many strange claims about beer that leave me uncertain as to what a "Californian Lager" might be.This pup pours a golden bodied liquid with a modest yet sustained creamy white head. The aroma has a grainy sweetness with a touch of candy corn. (Note to non-Yanks: "Candy corn" is a popular Halloween candy that saw its heyday WAY back when I was a kid... some time afore Hector was a pup.) They taste is quite beery, as friend cheap might say. Pretty much what the nose had advertized. Theres a soft earthy bitterness in the finish. Guess Ill stick with furrin loggers.

Pours clear golden with a soapy off-white head. The aroma has smooth lager maltiness, light nuttiness and phenolic spice. It has a medium crisp body with semi-sharp carbonation. The flavor starts with dry malt,crackers, tree bark and nuts. The finish adds spicy hops and phenols. Good easy drinking lager.

Surprisingly full of flavor and very easy to drink. Smooth texture. Fruity, beery and grainy malt flavors are clean, and they are rich and cracker-like in the finish. Moderate hop bitterness is very balancing. Big and rounded aromas of herbs and spices drift nicely into the aftertaste. Tremendously well-made pale lager.

UPDATED: JUL 2, 2014 Can. Pours crystal clear golden butterscotch, medium fizzy white head that mostly dissipates but leaves a nice residual and great lacing. So far so good... Aroma is grassy, notes of honey, grain and perhaps a bit of corn. Flavor is medium sweet, light plus bitter, grassy, a bit metallic on the finish but otherwise pretty crisp. Lightish body, bubbly carbonation, lingering bitterness into the far finish.Earlier Rating: 8/14/2013 Total Score: 3.5Taster. Pours clear pale golden, large white head, nice lacing. Aroma is grain, grass, faint citrus. Flavor is the same, little sweetness, brisk bitterness. Light body, refreshing, bitter far finish.

Anchor California Lager (canned version) has a thick, off-white head, a clear, bubbly, golden appearance, and heavy lacing left on the glass. The aroma is of malt, with a noticeable hop zing. Taste is of sweet barley malt and fairly significant hop bitterness. Mouthfeel is light to medium, and Anchor California Lager finishes crisp, refreshing, and highly drinkable. RJTEarlier Rating: 2/11/2014 Total Score: 3Anchor California Lager has a thin-to-medium white head, a clear, bubbly, gold appearance, and essentially no lacing left behind. The aroma is of bright, bursting, pungent barley malt and grain sugar. Taste is of sweet barley malt, sugar, a touch of honey, and a low background bitterness. Mouthfeel is light and a bit slick, and Anchor California Lager finishes mostly dry, easy drinking, and a bit dull. Overall, this is very good, but I dont think it is worth the price ($9.99 a six-pack). Michelob, at around $11.99 for a 12-pack, would be the better option. Plus, its more flavorful than this one.

RJT

Cerveza de color dorado, limpia y brillante. Tiene buena formación de espuma pero poco persistente. Destaca el aroma a malta que recuerda a pan y bizcocho. En boca aparece el lúpulo suave y refrescante de aroma y sabor herbáceo. Se trata de una cerveza de cuerpo leve y bien carbonatada. Una cerveza de diario.(Botella 355ml)

Pours a nice looking golden yellow with a huge white, pillowy head. Lots of bubbles streaming up. Aroma is sweet malts, and a definite hop presence; mostly tropical fruit and citrus. The taste is sweet up front with a bubble gum note in there. Finishes with a bit of hop flavor, this time more piney. Not thin and watery like most American lagers, but rather medium bodied and almost silky in the mouth feel. Overall this is an outstanding lager.

A golden body with a white head that faded away quickly. Light toasted malts on the nose some nice floral and grassy notes. Floral notes were more apparent in the flavor. Malts were mildly sweet but mostly lightly toasted malts. Nice crisp finish. Mild but well balanced. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

UPDATED: NOV 18, 2015 California Lager is an excellent tribute to the old-world German lagers. Its smooth flavor and bigger hop profile also make it American enough to bear the name of California Lager. In the end, its not very complex or unusual but its a gorgeous lager to look at. Also, the clean, refreshing feel is just right for quenching your thirst. I love the bottle artwork, too. That highly-detailed bear is awesome. Like most of the other bottles in Anchors inventory, this one is classy and distinctive.

Bottle at Old Fountain. It pours clear amber with a quickly dissipating white head. The nose is earthy, dough, spice, hay and light toast. The taste is crisp, bitter, grassy, spice, light toast, grain and biscuit backbone with a refreshing my dry finish. Medium body and fine, prickly carbonation. Good malty lager.

I have never met an Anchor beer that I did not absolutely love. They really are the best brewery in California, and maybe even more. This beer is inspired by an 1876 batch of brew made by Boca Brewery, a California brewery that made the states first Lager by harnessing the power of a frozen mountain pond. The beer is amazing. Get it at all costs.

Crisp amber with a nice foam. Definitely know you are drinking beer here. Interesting combination of hops and malt on the tongue. You can taste the grain and a nice spiciness. Long finish and aftertaste.

Presentation: It was poured from a brown 12 oz bottle into a tall pilsner glass. 
Appearance: It has a light golden body with some visible carbonation and a small white head that just hangs on to a thin layer of foam. Lacing is minimal. 
Smell: There are some light biscuity maltiness and some mild grassy hop notes. 
Taste / Palate: I am picking up the same biscuity and white bready maltiness. Its dry overall and finishes with some mild grassy/herbal/botanical hop bitterness.
Golden with nice white head. Metallic light sweet aroma, hint of candy. Malt, with strong metallic bitterness in the aftertaste. Could be better balance. High in carbon

355 ml bottle.
Pours clear golden color with a small white head. Quiet hay-dominant and herbal aroma, some faint malty notes, distant hops and some fruits. Bitter dry malty flavor, mild dry fruits and some hay. Quite straightforward and dull actually. Never would have guessed this to be a Anchor brew if tasted blind.

355 ml bottle from The Local Pub, Athens Greece. Golden color with a thin white head. Aromas of malts and some earthy notes (and alcohol???) . Bittersweet taste, malts first, caramel, and some astrigent earthy notes. Mild aftertaste, long. Sticky, oily mouthfeel, Light to medium body, medium carbonation.
Bottle. Golden color. Malty floral flavor, almost medium bodied. A moderate bitterness and an even more moderate aroma. Still a decent lager.
Bottle. Clear golden thin white head. Aroma of grass, hay, bread, basement aromas. Medium sweet taste. Light body, somewhat oily texture, light dry bitter finish. Good lager.
Poured from can into pint glass. Pours a light golden color with a medium head. aroma is a bitter hop smell. bitter taste, slightly carbonated. Thought it was just....ok.
Great airy hoppy taste. Easy drinkin, with enough base to it. Its like a real coors light. But has great depth and quality. One of my best favs ever.

Clear gold with lasting white head. Smell is grassy mostly and lesser so yeast. Taste is very traditional lager like with some yeasty flavours, light malt and some subtle balancing hops. Doughy but crisp. Actually a bit hoppier than your average lager. Aa

12 oz bottle. Pours golden with tall, long lasting, fluffy white head and nice lacing. Aroma is of piney hops and biscuit malt. Body is medium and crisp. Good amount of herbal hops balanced by biscuit malt on the palate. Finish is long and herbal. Nice summer brew.

Bottle. Pours a mostly clear dark golden color with a moderate white head on there. Nose is filled with corn and grains, just like your average lager you come across. Taste has the same grain elements in there, as well as a slight bit of earthiness. Meh.
Perfect beer for drinking to maintain. I keep thinking that Ill grow tired of drinking this, but I havent yet. Keep doing what you do Anchor!
Pale yellowish pour with a small fizzy head. Smells of citrus and caramel. Sweet citrus flavor with a bit of a bitter note. Overall a nice beer.

12 oz. can. Bright golden pour with a medium white head. Good lacing. Aroma is mildly fruity with some bread and dough notes. Flavor is crisp, clean, refreshing. Mild fruity and bread notes. Medium bodied, zippy carbonation. Dry, somewhat earthy finish. This is pretty nice.
Poured a pretty clear golden colour. Fluffy head that maintained throughout the pint. Grassy in the mouth. Not bad at all.

12 oz bottle purchased as a single at the spot next to my hotel in San Francisco. The pour is a clear golden with fine carbonation bubbles rising to the top of the beer. Not too much of a white head. The aroma is hay malt, grass and a bit of dustiness. The taste is dry cracker malt along with grass and hay. The palate is light bodied with active fine carbonation and a clean mineral finish. Solid, easy drinking beer.

Bottle bought in Utobeer at Borough Market. Clear pale amber out of the bottle, large foam white head. Nose is barley grain, crisp lager yeast, lots of nice grain malt aroma. Taste is a nice clean crisp, malty lager with some lingering prickly lager bitterness. Decent and refreshing.

From the 12 fl. oz. bottle stamped with something that looks like 1-FL. Highly carbonated pale yellow pour leading up to a fizzy white head. The aroma is pretty basic with its pale malts, toasted biscuit, and clean hop note. The body is light to medium. The taste has an abundance of sweetness in the malts that make up the recipe. Very thin bitterness at the end. Yet it was enjoyable.
(Bottle). Golden complexion with minimal head retained. Faint malt and metallic aroma. The flavor is a simple mild malt. Very mediocre. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle at Black & Brown. 
Drinkable US lager on the malty side with some orange hops.
Poured from a bottle it is an effervescent golden lager with a slight hearthrug aroma is malty and the taste is a light weight brew that has some bitterness at the finish

Tap. Light to moderate bread and grain for the malt, light herbs for the hops, light dough for the yeast, with a hint of damp wood. Head is average size, frothy/creamy, white with fair lacing and is mostly lasting. Color is sparkling clear light amber. Flavor starts lightly sweet and acidic, then finishes lightly to moderately bitter. Palate is light to medium, watery with a lively carbonation. Tasty, easy drinking Premium Lager.
From a 12 oz bottle in Avon, NC. Pours a hazy gold with an off white head. Light caramel nose. Flavors of butterscotch and white bread. Crisp finish with a bit of bitterness.
Medium gold pour, 1 finger head that leaves quickly. Nose is lightly roasted grain. Bitter. Middle is medium malt with hints of metal. Finish is scouring bitterness, crisp and sharp.
Pretty good, pours golden with good head and lacing. Very good for a lager. Nice hoppy finish with sharp barley grain crispness. Cluster hops come out well. Tap at Summerfest DC.

Clear, maple gold. BIg ivory head. Slope-shouldered Anchor 12ozer with a good label and cap. Cereal, sweetish malt lager aroma. Sweet, smooth, nicely bitter, a little astringent, malty. Mouthy, with a cereal finish. There is nothing that really stands out about this beer, except for its balance and incredible drinkability. Well done. ABC, Betton.

Bottle pour. Clear dark gold with full white head. Aroma is light, but pleasant. Grainy with trace hops. Taste expands. Vegetal, a bit of sulfur. A mild, underlying sweetness. Overall, a really solid lager.

Draught @ In de Wildeman. Clear golden color, medium sized lightly off-white head that lasts for a decent while. Aroma is very faint, probably due to it being served very cold. Taste is nothing out of the ordinary: malts, slightly grains, nicely bitter. Decent lager.

Bottle shared thanks to Deanso. Pours clear golden with an off white head. Aroma of grain, caramel, malt and toffee. Flavour is light moderate sweet and bitter. Light medium bodied with soft carbonation.

355ml bottle from Bier&zO.
Thin white head. Clear golden pour. Nice and hoppy. A decent lager.
UPDATED: DEC 14, 2015 Aroma of biscuity malt, grass, touch of lemon. Flavour is more biscuit, little bit of sweetness. Decent Lager.
Tap from Lazy Dog. Pours a bright golden with a thin layer of cream colored head. Aroma is very mild. Taste similar, not much.

Draught @ Wildeman.
Pours clear golden, with quick fading white head.
Nose malty and bit hard candy.
Round mouthfeel, malty again, light bitter finish.
Okay
A clear copper beer with a small white head. The aroma is light grains and hay. The flavor is slightly bitter hops, citrus, and grain.

Rustic hop bitterness under the cap, more like a Northern Brewer. Foams up a lot when poured into my Sam Adams glass. Just a tad darker than the usual pale lager color, while most old-time lagers (Juengling, Sam) tend to be darker. That slight oxidation that comes with most light lagers. Taste is both highly bittered from that "all-purpose hop," and a bit sweet. If they used a truly historical 2-row barley, they might have had to amp it up with adjunct. An interesting beer, but its a little too close to a Pabst for me.

Draught: Small sample in a taster:
Medium sized creamy head on top of a cloudy yellow colored beer.
Aroma is a mix of the typical pils aromas, mostly the pils malts, with some crispyness, light fruity and light flower tones.
Flavour has some flowers with cream and bitters with some hay, malts and a fruity sprinkle.
Aftertaste has some bitters with flowers.
Low carbo, creamy mouthfeel, medium bodied and a creamy texture.
Great stuff.
user_location: Best of E-Town mit 2 Brauhausen, NETHERLANDS

text: The aroma is spot on for the style with grassy hops and malt with just a touch of yeasty bread. The appearance is golden with a delicate head. The taste is spot on too with all the elements from with aroma and well balanced hops and malt. The palate is smooth. Overall one of the best examples of the style I have had.

Pours a golden yellow color with a hay aroma. Taste is grainy with a dry finish. A slighly bitter finish after the swallow. A light dirty flavor which I attribute to the tap water used when making this beer. Overall a decent lager iI enjoyed on a trip in SF.
Pours a golden frothy, somewhat like hay. Big white foamyness, aroma of floral hays with a medium bitterness. Sorta metallic, but comes in clean and refreshing. Decent I suppose.
user_location: The Crystal Coast, North Carolina, USA

text: Bottle into a tulip glass. Pour is a yellow with a thick head. Aroma is light but grass and malt. Taste is a bitter wash and corse malt. Finish is a nice bitter.

Aroma: malty, grain, bread. Appearance: clear gold, medium creamy white head. Taste: light bitter. Palate: refreshing light bitters, malty, fizzy carbonation. Overall: boring Lager, lacks complexity and flavours on all fronts. Bottle at The Caledonian, Carlisle.

Aroma isnt much. Clear gold beer pours with few bubbles but has a lasting white head. The malty grain sweetness in the flavor I dont care for but it is an exceptionally crisp beer with appreciable bitterness.

Bottle. Pours a clear, lambent gold with a high, large-grained, cream-colored head with lots of visible carbonation and lace. Nose is lime, wheat toast, gardenias, and a touch of burnt malt; its quite weak. Somewhat vegetal on the front of the tongue, with butterscotch malt kicking in right after; the vegetal note turns herbal with substantial body and bitterness on the back of the tongue. Finish is medium to long with citric lime notes. Not a bad lager, but nothing really notable about it. No flaws, but no hook either.

Bottle from Save On. Clear golden with lasting head and lace and rising bubbles. Mild bready grassy woody aroma. Mild crackery honey sweetness with very clean grassy woody mildly bitter finish. Light body. Effervescent carbo. It is what it is, which is pretty good. Wonder how like it will continue to take for Anchor to go big.

Bottle. Golden with a white foam. Aromas are bready with nutty cereal and herbal notes. Hints of lime with apple and spices. Flavours are nutty and grainy with herbal leafiness and base biscuit. Green apple with spices. Grew on me.
Crisp and dry, bone dry, but tasty. Pleasing malt aroma, small light and fluffy head, golden clear body. Taste is malt and bread, saltine crackers, abrupt finish, but refreshing.
Gold with a white head. Malts, bread, faint hops. Smooth palate, bready malts, sweet, toffee, easy finish

On tap @ In De De Wildeman. Clear golden blonde color. Uneven white head with pretty good lacing. Aromas: somewhat malty sweet, but also some fruitiness. Retronasal theres grain/malt, light sweetness with a delictae hop aroma. Flavor is grainish/malty, light sweet with a light bitterness. Light bodied, not too thin. Good bitterness eventually. Solid lager, quite German.

Bottle-pours lite orange with a small soapy white head and no lacing. nose is somewhat musty-wet grains, sort of wet cardboard thing going on. I dont think this beer is that old, i think they just use old or shitty malt. flavors exhibit these wet cardboard and cracker like malt profile. long grainy finish with some very faint spicy hops but pretty dull hop profile. really not into this one very much. i wonder what it is like on fresh tap?

smells like my minds nose-vision of what beer should smell like. The smell I conjured up while watching the simpsons in grade school. Homer would drool over a beer and I would imagine a smell like this. Its not a great smell nor is it a bad one. It just is a beer smell. Appearance is hard for me to judge. I dont have many biasses and usually think most brown transparent liquids look healthy to me. This does not taste like a traditional lager, which is a shift from what the aroma would suggest. I find it tangy and sweet. Slightly bitter. A taste that comes on strong initially but eventually fades the more I sip(i suppose that is the case for all beer). I didnt love the palate and decided to give it a modest 3. It sparkled in the mouth a little too long. Overall I am enjoying the beer and happy I purchased it at 2.99 for a single bottle.

Pint on tap at Beer Revolution in Edmonton pours a copper color with a finger of white head that leaves some spotty lacing on the glass. Aroma is mild with grains and grass. Taste is a grassy and spicy hop bitterness with a grainy malt sweetness. Light to medium body with decent carbonation.

355ml brown bottle. Clear yellow pour. White cap, creamy. Spotty lace. Nose has cereal/grains with light sweetness. Taste has grains, bit of herbal hops. Clean finish with a light leafy hop aftertaste and light bittering. Overall a good clean lager, good session beer.

Pour from a 12oz bottle. Clear golden brew with white head. Pleasant lightly hoppy aroma. Taste is mild sweet malt at the start with a nicely hoppy finish. A full bodied and flavorful lager that holds true to lager style - very good.
UPDATED: JUN 29, 2014 Straight from the bottle after a long day of cleaning and a nice walk. Nice lager with some character. The hops are there but they don?t linger long. Refreshing. Cool story too.

Medium gold and sparkling with very fine, intermittent carbonation. Loose, Sudsy wash of white atop is mostly lasting. Strange, weedy, dried herb and tea leaf nose with a hint of marijuana and haybales, mouse fur and lemon peel. Light bodied with medium, spritzy carbonation. Lagered well with low, grainy malt and dusty hops mid-palate. Earthy, mildly bitter finish that is crisp. Clean and straightforward. Sessionable but rather undemanding. Average! (12fl.Oz, BB 20/12/15, The Liquor Shed, Jandakot)
Warm, roasted flavor. Settles nicely on the palate, but has a "foamy" feel to it. A nice session beer, it also is great for cooking. A good example of a well made lager.
UPDATED: APR 12, 2014 Whoa, this is a first rate lager, cereal, rye bread, hay and a hint of green apple. Full bodied and crisp. This would be a great grillin beer.

A little surprised to see this today at the COOP... Picked up a few bottles and am getting to one while taking care of some business for tomorrow... 

Poured into my thin tulip.. clear golden.. small bubble white head rises up and drops pretty quickly but the cap leaves nice drapes of lacing.

Nose shows clean pale malt with just enough hoppiness to balance.. smells fantastic.

Good balanced bitterness that just allows a subtle pale malt sweetness to get interesting... Hop flavors are sorta grassy and inviting.. This is a really well done brew.. Perfect for an evening barbecue.. 

Light/medium body ... good bubble.. nicely drinkable..

The appearance has a clear golden yellow colored body with a half finger foamy white head that dies and leaves some thick foamy white lacing that spiderwebs pretty nice. The carbonation is seen rising at a moderate pace.
The smell has some light citrusy-fruit with a decent cracker-like spice coming through kinda peppery.
The taste has a lager-like sweetness strong with that nice cracker-like spice blending pretty nice along with a sweet cracker-like aftertaste with a clean sweet dry finish.
On the palate, it sits fairly light on the body with a decent to moderate harshness trying to take a bite, but actually stays somewhat smooth for the most part. There is a decent sessionability for this one.
Overall, this is a good American Pale Lager well worthy of coming back to, Ill look to have this one definitely again in the summer months. Also, I would say this would definitely be a well worthy transition beer for BMC drinkers.

Draft at Dutchs. Pours a clear yellow golden color with a small white head. The aroma and flavor have bready and biscuity malt, earthy and lightly bittering hops, grass, some yeast. Worth trying, just not my thing.

This tastes to me basically like Pilsner in which the traditional noble hops were substituted for American cluster hops. That is all well and good but, honestly, clusters are just not very good tasting hops. I am not sure how this escaped the notice of Anchors "Zymasters" but apparently someone was asleep at the switch. I do like the idea of recreating a traditional and forgotten American style in theory but you dont wind up drinking the idea and this beer is just not all that great. 


As mentioned, it is somewhat along the lines of a Czech Pilsener. There is just a touch of malt character and a good amount of hops in both the nose in the finish. The hop character itself is sort of strangely tutt-fruity and the bitterness in the finish is astringent, giving this a drying quality on the tongue. It strikes me as well made beer in general in that there doesnt seem to be any oxidation or any kind of flaws that might be the result of poor process control but it simply doesnt taste all that great at the end of the day.

12 oz bottle into a pint glass.

A: Pours a clear golden color. The head is about one fingers high, and barely off-white. Retention is acceptable, and the lacing is thin yet consistent.

S: Typically lager-y: tons of cracker, a touch of lemon, and some grass generally comprise the aroma. No twists, turns, or excitement here; it is well-done though.

T: Apart from the crackery malts, there are some diacetyl elements right before the finish: they neither take away nor take it to the next level. The finish is slightly lemony. Not much to say about this one, really.

M: The malt backbone seems to cut in during the swallow, creating a brew thats just a hair too full. Meanwhile, its hoppiness does a reasonable job of drying the (otherwise sweetish) finish out. Carbonation - if not low - is at least gentle.

O: A competent lager and a nice history lesson, just not very exciting. Its rather boring, frankly, but it would go well with food.

12 ounce bottle into lager glass, bottled on 12/3/2013. Pours crystal clear pale golden amber color with a 1-2 finger fairly dense white head with great retention, that reduces to a nice cap that lingers. Spotty soapy lacing clings down the glass, with a good amount of streaming carbonation retaining the head. Aromas of lemon, pear, apple, cracker, bread, herbal, floral, grass, light pepper, and herbal/yeast earthiness. Nice and pleasant aromas with good balance of malt, hop, and yeast ester notes; with solid strength. Taste of lemon, pear, apple, cracker, bread, herbal, floral, grass, light pepper, and herbal/yeast earthiness. Slight earthy bitterness on the finish; with lingering notes of cracker, bread, pear, apple, herbal, floral, grass, light pepper, and herbal/yeast earthiness on the finish for a good bit. Very pleasant, clean, and well balanced malt, hop, and yeast ester flavors; with solid robustness without feeling watery, and zero cloying flavors after the finish. Medium carbonation and body; with a very smooth and crisp mouthfeel that is nice. Alcohol is very well hidden with minimal warming present after the finish. Overall this is a nice pale lager style. Well balanced hop, malt, and yeast ester flavors; and very smooth and crisp to drink. A nicely enjoyable offering.

12 oz bottle, Kroger, Bridge St., $1.69. Pale golden-straw pour; white almost-fizzy head doesnt hold at all, and quickly this beer is just a glass of orange liquid. If were going to compare this to Budweiser, then yeah, this is 10 times better. Versus almost anything else, this is pretty unimpressive. 95th percentile for the style, yes; but folks are sucking the Anchor teet pretty hard for this to be 70th percentile overall. Sorry, Anchor, but Im not paying 10 bucks a sixer for this.

Bottle. Nose is very pleasantly malty in a very traditional way, some notes of caramel, toffee, earth, even getting some good yeast character, but really its just depth of malt thats wowing me. Taste is medium bitter, semi-dry with some earthen and resinous moods, malt with cigarette ash underpinnings, corn, and thin but sticky caramel that seems to have been stretched into long ribbons. Light-medium body not what Im looking for, but does help the drinkability here. Theres this Anchor soda thing going on, this one note I sometimes find in between their bubbles, usually chalking up to house character that is a negative tweak Im able to overlook. Some weird things going on here, and a second opinion might call this unclean instead of unique; it does share some qualities with dirty German and Polish lagers Ive had, but in the current marketplace, Im enthused!

Bottle from The Davis Co-Op. Pours dark gold with a creamy white head. Floral aroma - hints of perfume. Full bodied. Flavor is a mix of floral, earth, spice.Sort of hallertau gone wild. Its hoppy in a non-harsh way, and the same for bitter. Not sure about malt. I know its in here. Pretty interesting.
On draft at Blue Monkey. Nice black pour some notes of roast and coffee with some mild hop bitterness. A bit thin in the body, but ok.

Pour on tap, clear yellow pour with white head, aroma brought notes of slight grain, biscuit, bread, hints of vanilla, slight grassy and herbal notes, slightly odd.  Taste is a mix of slightly grainy notes with some bread, hints of vanilla, nice grass, grain, floral notes, hints of earth, finishing fairly sweet, slightly bitter.

Pours a super clear dark yellow.  Aroma  is more of a sweet wheat.  Flavor is primarily wheat with a nice bit hops.  Some citrus amongst the malt taste.  Could use a little more carbonation to add some zing.

Poured up on tap at GABF 2012 (also had this at the Pleasanton Hopyard back in 02/12 didnt bother rating for some reason) with a crystal clear gold body supporting a nice firm light tan colored head of foam. The aroma offers up sweet and lagery notes with a sort of Bohemian Pilsener sort of feel as well as a bit of floral hops. The taste is pleasing and refreshing as it delivers some fresh bready to grainy malts and then it gets a thin pulse of modestly bitter hops coming to the surface. Off into the finish it leaves behind a classic lagery yeastiness. Great session-y as well as hot weather summer beer.
GABF 2012. Pours a golden appearance with a white head. Grainy, straw, a bit dry, light vanilla aroma. Grainy, a touch fruity, straw, pretty tasty flavor. Pretty tasty, easy drinking beer.

Aroma carries a big nitrogen component, and the head confirms. Behind the head is a sweetness and an almost cocoa note. Taste is sweet and light despite the full red color - almost reminds me of seltzer water.

A - Served a clear golden-orange color with a bit of frothy white head. The head faded down at a normal pace leaving behind some lacing.

S - Aroma is a mix of grains and some sweet malt with some lemon peel, a touch of citrus hop, and some lager esters.

T - Starts off with a mix of sweet grains with a bit of bready malts and some lemon peel. Through the middle, a bit more citrus fruits come through with a bit more bready malts. The finish is a mix of sweet grains and malts with some light hop and a bit of lager yeast.

M - Medium bodied with moderate carbonation. Feels smooth with a crisp and dry finish.

D - Very drinkable. Nicely balanced and very crisp.
tap at burger. pours amber orange, decent white head. not much of an aroma, taste of malt, clean crisp beer. Nicely done, curious to see more.
Tap @ The BeerMongers...  Poured amber with a white-ish head.  Straight up malty lager.  Caramel, earthy, vege-hop flavors. Mild sweetness with a clean finish.

On tap at FO1. Pours with a crystal clear orange hued body with a lasting white head that leaves good lace. Aromas are malty, bready, grassy, light esters, appley and some toasty malt (munich-esque). Flavors are grassy, bready, biscuity, sweet, distinct cluster hop character (not a fan), grassy, medium fruit. Medium to medium high bitterness. Medium to full carbonation, brief, finish, medium bodied.

Tap at Fathers Office - Santa Monica.  Pours clear orange with a medium, fizzy white head, short retention with light lacing.  Aroma is fruity esters, cookie and honey malt, vanilla and earthy hops.  Flavor is malt forward with medium hops and bitterness, fruity esters and a sweet finish.  Light body and warmth with medium carbonation.
Draft. Amber beer with an off-white head. Malt and light earth aroma. Grain and malt flavor with light mineral notes. Medium bodied. Grain and mineral lingers with malt.

On draft at the Hopyard in Pleasanton. I was excited to try this one. It pours golden yellow with a nice off white head, very effervescent with lots of streaming bubbles. This looks really nice in the glass. The aroma has lots of cereal grains, some pungent earthy hops and light notes of berries. The flavor is a nice balance of bready grains, mild fruity esters (could be the fruity hops) and a bitter, lightly sulfery hop/lager yeast finish. Similar to the Steam beer, but a bit lighter and a tad drier. Nice one.
